title: AgCl vs AgF - cool soln 85-50C - Sn plus AgNO3

content.question: Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. A student investigates various properties of silver compounds in the lab. First, the student carries out the following procedure to determine the concentration of <math alttext="A g with a positive one charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>g</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in a solution of <math alttext="A g N O 3, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>N</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. The student adds an excess of <math alttext="2.0 molar H C l, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="300.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>300.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>m</mtext><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the solution, causing <math alttext="A g C l, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to precipitate. The precipitate is separated from the solution by filtering it through a pre-weighed piece of filter paper. The precipitate and filter paper are rinsed with distilled water, dried, and weighed. The data from the experiment are given in the table below. Initial mass of filter paper <math alttext="0.650 gram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>0.650</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> Mass of filter paper + <math alttext="A g C l, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> precipitate after drying <math alttext="0.793 gram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>0.793</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> (a) Calculate the number of moles of <math alttext="A g C l, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> that precipitated. (The molar mass of <math alttext="A g C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="143 grams per mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>143</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>m</mtext><mtext>o</mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>).

frqParts.text: Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. A student investigates various properties of silver compounds in the lab. First, the student carries out the following procedure to determine the concentration of <math alttext="A g with a positive one charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>g</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in a solution of <math alttext="A g N O 3, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>N</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. The student adds an excess of <math alttext="2.0 molar H C l, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="300.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>300.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>m</mtext><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the solution, causing <math alttext="A g C l, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to precipitate. The precipitate is separated from the solution by filtering it through a pre-weighed piece of filter paper. The precipitate and filter paper are rinsed with distilled water, dried, and weighed. The data from the experiment are given in the table below. Initial mass of filter paper <math alttext="0.650 gram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>0.650</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> Mass of filter paper + <math alttext="A g C l, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> precipitate after drying <math alttext="0.793 gram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>0.793</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> (a) Calculate the number of moles of <math alttext="A g C l, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> that precipitated. (The molar mass of <math alttext="A g C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="143 grams per mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>143</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>m</mtext><mtext>o</mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>).

(b) Assuming that all of the <math alttext="A g with a positive one charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext></mtext><mtext>g</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> ions precipitated, calculate the original molarity of <math alttext="A g with a positive one charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext></mtext><mtext>g</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the solution before <math alttext="H C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> was added.

(c) The calculated concentration of <math alttext="A g with a positive one charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>g</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> from the student’s data is lower than the actual concentration of the original solution. The student claims that the calculated concentration is too low because some of the <math alttext="A g C l, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCl</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> passed through the filter paper. Do you agree or disagree? Justify your answer.

After the experiment, the student learns that the precipitate, <math alttext="A g C l, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo>(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, is slightly soluble in water. To determine the solubility, the student mixes a sample of the precipitate with warm, distilled water to make a saturated solution. The student finds the following equation for the dissolution of <math alttext="A g C l, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo>(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> in water and a <math alttext="K s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> value at the temperature of the water.<math alttext="A g C l solid is in equilibrium with A g with a positive one charge aqueous plus Cs l with a negative one charge aqueous. K s p equals 9.0 times 10 raied to the power of negative 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><mtext>A</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>g</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext>C</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>l</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="1.0em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="2.0em"></mspace><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>9.0</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>(d) Calculate <math alttext="the molar concentration of A g with a positive one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>A</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>g</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the student’s solution.

(e) The value of <math alttext="K s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> of another silver salt, <math alttext="A g F, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>gF</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, is <math alttext="2.0 times 10 raised to the power of 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.0</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. If separate, saturated solutions of <math alttext="A g F, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>gF</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="A g C l, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCl</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> are prepared, which solution will have the greater <math alttext="molar concentration of A g with a positive one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>A</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>g</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>? Justify your answer.

(f) The student finds the following particulate model of <math alttext="A g C l, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. Assuming the crystal structures are similar, how should the student modify the model to represent <math alttext="A g F, solid?" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>gF</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>? Justify your answer in terms of the radius and arrangement of electrons in the ions.

(g) The enthalpy of dissolution of <math alttext="A g C l, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in water is a positive value. Based on this information, the student claims that the energy required to separate the ions in <math alttext="A g C l, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is equal to the energy released during the hydration of <math alttext="A g with a positive one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>g</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C l with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>l</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> by water molecules. Do you agree or disagree with the student’s claim? Justify your answer.

The student then conducts an experiment to determine the solubility of <math alttext="A g C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in a <math alttext="2.5 molar N a C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.5</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution at various temperatures. Some <math alttext="A g C l, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> remains in the container at all temperatures studied. The data are plotted on the graph below. (h) A <math alttext="1000 decimal point gram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1000.</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of a saturated solution at <math alttext="85 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>85</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is cooled to <math alttext="50 decimal point degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Determine the mass of <math alttext="A g C l, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> that would precipitate out of the solution.

(i) The specific heat capacity of the solution is <math alttext="3.4 joules per gram degree Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.4</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>J</mtext><mo>/</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>g</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> . How much heat is released when <math alttext="1000 decimal point grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1000.</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the solution is cooled from <math alttext="85 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>85</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="50 decimal point degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>?

(j) The student finds that <math alttext="A g C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is more soluble in <math alttext="N a C l, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> than in water because of the series of reactions above. Determine the value of <math alttext="K sub 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> for the overall reaction.

To further investigate the reactivity of silver, the student submerges a piece of metallic tin, <math alttext="S n, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mtext>S</mtext><mtext>n</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, in a solution of <math alttext="A g N O 3, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>N</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and observes that the following reaction occurs.<math alttext="S n solid plus 2 A g N O 3 aqueous react to produce 2 A g solid plus S n open parenthesis N O 3 close parenthesis 2 aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext><mtext>n(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext> Ag</mtext><mtext>N</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext> Ag</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>Sn</mtext><mo>(</mo><mtext>N</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>(k) Write the balanced net-ionic equation for the reaction.

(l) The mass of the <math alttext="S n, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mtext>S</mtext><mtext>n</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> decreases significantly as it sits in the <math alttext="A g N O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mtext>N</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> solution. The student claims that the mass decreases because the atoms in <math alttext="S n, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mtext>S</mtext><mtext>n</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> are converted to atoms of <math alttext="A g, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> as the experiment progresses, and <math alttext="A g, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> has a smaller molar mass than <math alttext="S n, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mtext>S</mtext><mtext>n</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> has. Does the student’s claim accurately explain the decrease in the mass of the <math alttext="S n, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mtext>S</mtext><mtext>n</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>? Justify your answer.

skill.text: 2.D: Make observations or collect data from representations of laboratory setups or results, while attending to precision where appropriate.
